Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I glance at my phone, heart sinking as I read the urgent Slack messages: “Production is down. Users can’t log in. Can you look now?” My laptop is already open, error logs scrolling past, my mind racing to trace the bug. But then I hear a soft sigh from the couch. My partner sits hunched, eyes red, clutching a crumpled email. He barely looks up as I approach, but I can feel the weight of his disappointment filling the room. He needs me—needs comfort, reassurance, someone to listen. I want to drop everything, wrap him in my arms, and tell him it’ll be okay. But the outage is critical; customers are locked out, and the team is waiting for me to fix it. My inbox pings again, more frantic messages. I’m torn, guilt gnawing at me. I can’t be in two places at once, can’t give my full self to both. My hands hover over the keyboard, my eyes flicker to my partner. I feel the pressure mounting, the impossible choice pressing in from both sides.
